args.content: Cetra: have you imported the trait?
Yeah, I did, I worked around it by double boxing
so instead of (*fut).and_then()
I do Box::new(fut.and_then())
which isn't ideal, but I can't work out how to unbox a Future and then return a new box with a different future return type
you, uh, can't move a trait object out of a box, generally speaking
so double boxing is the way to go?
Unless I provide a struct which impls Future I guess
either implement `Future` by hand, use an existing impl, contrive to avoid returning a future at all, or use `impl Trait`
impl trait is due to be stabilized soon, isn't it?
May 10th, iirc
can I use impl Trait with returning futures instead of lots of boxes?
Cetra: I believe so
I thought there were some restrictions on the initial implementation that made it a bit unergonomic for futures
Cetra, it's fine now afaik
I thought impl Trait was one of the things that would make futures actually ergonomic
Cetra, i haven't had any issue
I have not played around with futures much so I can't confirm
I have lots of Box<Future> return types for functions, so I'm hoping that it's a matter of just adjusting that and not returning boxes
I think you can just return impl Future
you still have to indicate Item/Error of course
crate B optionally depends on crate A, meaning you can build it with --features A ; crate C depends on both A and B. shouldn't feature A of B be enabled by default?

Hi there. I'm having an issue implementing a trait. I get an error E0049 which says that I'm not implementing a type parameter. I'm using nalgebra, and I genuinely don't understand why cargo is complaining. I'm using in a very similar way to what I know works... https://gist.github.com/ChristopherRabotin/6d49e97a39eb8d9b3231f2cb813a2e3b
Note that Vector6<f64> is a shortcut for VectorN<f64, U6>, and U6 implements "Dim" and "DimName". That's why I don't understand why I'm getting this error
xionbox: The method `state` in the trait is defined as being generic
Mutabah: So I can't force "TwoBody" dynamics to only be a Vector6? It must be a VectorN ?
xionbox: seems like you want to use an associated trait
*type
associated type
on the Dynamics trait
so instead of having generic methods returning a VectorN<f64, N>, they'd be returning the associated type
Does rust have a operator like '<-'?
glandium: so I'd define `type N;` in the Dynamics trait.And in the implementation I would code `type N = U6;` ?
TodayIAmARustNoob: what are you trying to do?
I could have sworn I saw that go by a couple of days ago, but I didn't not where I saw it.
xionbox: yes
scottmcm: learn.
glandium: okay, thanks, I'll try that out
TodayIAmARustNoob: That operator used to be for placement new
TodayIAmARustNoob: it was removed from nightly about a week ago
Mutabah: ah, thanks.  (What is "placement new"?)
TodayIAmARustNoob: The ability to construct an object inpre-allocated memory
ah.  thanks!
s/new/in/ (iirc "placement in" was the actual name of the feature)
ah, okay.  That makes more sense.  Thanks!
Ah, that's where I saw it, the first-book.  Makes sense why I couldn't find it in the second book!  https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/expressions.html
glandium: awesome thank you, that seems to work! (well, I have other compilation errors but they are unrelated)
Can I use a trait function as a parameter of type Fn ?
I get the following error: error[E0615]: attempted to take value of method `eom` on type `nyx::dynamics::celestial::TwoBody` when I attempt to use it
xionbox: you can't turn `thing.method` into a Fn, but you can `Trait::method`
SpaceManiac: okay. Now, if I do Trait::method, then I cannot use the specific data from an instance of that trait. Right?
You'd have to arrange for it to be passed
Alternatively, a closure: |arg| thing.method(arg)
Oh yeah, that's clever
Hello! I'm running into "can't find crate for compiler_builtins" on nightly when compiling a (statically linked) crate for a non-standard target.
It used to be (around a month ago) just "can't find crate for core" which I fixed by manually compiling libcore and forcing cargo to use a wrapper rustc that passed -L.
However, this doesn't seem to work for compiler_builtins:/ I can successfully manually compile libcompiler_builtins, but doing the same wrapper -L trick does not cause cargo to find it.
A question for the ages: If I have a lib that has "cydylib", "static", and "rlib" defined in the toml, how can I over-ride the crate-type with cargo so that lto can be run for the non-rlib targets?
SpaceManiac: I wonder if it wouldn't be useful for thing.method to be automatically desugared to |arg, ...| thing.method(arg, ...)
Without dumping down to manual compile with rustc only...
luke_nukem[m]-M: `cargo rustc` probably
icasdri: https://users.rust-lang.org/t/psa-breaking-change-extern-crate-compiler-builtins-is-now-included-in-no-std-crates/16704
luke_nukem[m]-M: afaik, you can't
glandium: thanks for the link!
glandium: cargo needs a crate-type override... Damn it. So I have to manually remove "rlib" when I want to to a specific build.
Oh wait... I can perhaps specify crate type depending on the target.
No go - warning: unused manifest key: target.wasm32-unknown-emscripten.crate-type
You could   #![cfg_attr(target = "...", crate_type = "...")]   but I don't know if rustc will take that to override what cargo gives it on the commandline
Arnavion: it doesn't
which is annoying
What does it do? Complain about the conflict or just ignore the attribute?
Arnavion: the latter
Sucks
Highly annoying. Forces you to do all sorts of gymnastics to get a crate building for static/cdylib and wasm.
Going to attempt bunging a "main()" in the libunder a feature flag and see if that helps (with associated [[bin]] in toml)

tools for identifying the cause of code in a loop running slower when other code is added to the loop? Presumably it might be something like the cpu cache, if so is there any way to reduce the loss?(1ms to 4ms)
nick_: perf?
callgrind, too
those show time spent executing something right?
or is there a way to get more info to understand why the added code is affecting the same code I'm measuring that isn't changed in my loop?
nick_: look at the compiled code?
I'm not sure if it's due to compiler, when I had similar issue, I did a basic version in godbolt and it only seemed to add one extra instruction between my code and the added code in the loop
nick_, you can measure various things with perf, including cache misses
write a microbenchmark that tortures that loop and thencompare aggregate stats
O_o moving code from one module to another broke type inference within that code
ah no, I had a duplicate line
Using Rayon, is there a nice way to join all the threads every nth iteration, do something, and then resume parallel iteration where it was left off?
I.e., I'm iterating over 60,000 elements but every 100 I need to mutate something based on the results of the previous 100 iterations. The iterations are independent beyond that single mutation.
so each 100 item chunk is processed in parallel?
and the chunks should be processed serially?
The 100 can be processed in parallel and the chunks serially, yes
The parallel processing requires immutable access to a struct but the struct needs to be mutated after each chunk
I'm writing an neural network library to prove to myself that I really understand the math and it would be great if Rayon would make parallel minibatches easy
I've got single threaded SGD working well but this stuff is crazy slow if it's not running on SIMD and/or GPU
neachdainn: couldn't you split the vec into chunks and then fire off a parallel operation on the chunks in a loop or so
Yes. Yes I could.
Thank you for the suggestion!
So I just finished the Rust book...  https://i.imgur.com/bmrowLx.png

In tokio, is there a way to unsubscribe from socket reads until a later time? I want to have an explicitly-managed buffer pool for decoding incoming streams and pause reading if there are no more available buffers. I've pinged the tokio gitter as well
cswl: dat static linking doe
ohay, when should you use #[inline]?
I tend to just trust the compiler[*] to inline automatically when it would be beneficial
Moonlightning: On short methods that you'd want to be inlined in downstream crates (iirc)
(I believe that marking as #[inline] enables saving of the MIR in the metadata)
why "static XXX: *const Type" doesn't work but "staticmut XXX: *const Type" works...?
Are you sure?
Mutabah: are you asking me or?
yes. How does the first case not work?
ACTION wonders if there is playbot in this channel
eval: static A: *const u32 = ::std::ptr::null();

args: error[E0277]: the trait bound `*const u32: std::marker::Sync` is not satisfied

args.content: eval: static mut A: *const u32 = ::std::ptr::null();
Aaah... yes, `static` requires Sync
Mutabah: ^
eval: const A: *const u32 = ::std::ptr::null();
oooh, so things can't be inlined automatically between crates!
xidorn: Maybe const is what you want?
Mutabah: no, because I need #[no_mangle]
Ah, so you need an external read-only variable that is a`*const u32`
right
why does "static" has more restriction than "static mut"?
Moonlightning: not without lto
xidorn: try using the static mut, and you'll see that'sthe one with restrictions
xidorn: `static` is safe to access from any thread
Moonlightning: can you give brief summary about #[inline]? I have been wondering it myself lately, but not yet dived into studying it.
glandium: because you cannot access it without unsafe at all?
Meanwhile, as glandium just implied, `static mut` is not(you need an unsafe block to access it)
Do the initializers for TLS have to be const fn?
and you can access static safely?
xidorn: yes
xidorn: but only if the type is Sync
glandium: then can I unsafely make a !Sync static?
xidorn: No, use static mut. Or don't put a raw pointer in there, and put a Sync value.
xidorn: What's that static for?
nox: for putting some value that C++ code can access
xidorn: How do you put that value in it?
nox: I know a fixed length array is interopable, but lesssure how can I put a variable length array there
I don't understand what you mean, where is the pointer valuecoming for, and how does it end up in the static?
nox: static XXX: *const u32 = &[1, 2, 3] as *const u32;
I see.
I don't think "static XXX: &[u32]" would work, would it?
static XXX: MyFancyArrayWrapper = MyFancyArrayWrapper(&[1, 2, 3] as *const u32)
and Sync for MyFancyArrayWrapper?
xidorn: why not static XXX: [u32; 3] = [1, 2, 3]?
Using &'static [u32] directly would work but then it's painful to get on the C++ side,
glandium: because you don't know the length in C++ side
but yeah just don't use a pointer and do like glandium said.
xidorn: How would you know the length in the C++ side with apointer?
xidorn: bindgen should know
nox: sentinel
glandium: bindgen works only if the data is flowed from the C++...
cbindgen is a thing.
oherrala: #[inline] marks a function for inlining--that is, calls to the function will be optimized into the contents of the function.
Moonlightning: may be optimized*
nox: not sure we have that in gecko, though
may be, yeah.
glandium: wr uses it
glandium: We use it for mp4parse at least.
nox: that's potentially be a cycle dependency
*may be inlined :P
#[inline(always)] forces, but you shouldn't use itunless you know what you're doing
#[inline(never)] prevents, and ditto
xidorn: Then maybe just use a &'static [i32;0] computed fromthe actual &'static [i32]
Moonlightning: generics can be inlined cross-crate
Generics can still benefit from #[inline] though.
nox: does reference work at all? I know that "static XXX: [u32; LEN] = ..." works
nox: but less sure about any reference...
xidorn: Why wouldn't they?
nox: isn't slice reference special in rust?
I said a &'static [i32; 0] from a &'static [i32].
The latter is fat, but the former is thin.
hmmm
I can probably try
Is there any way to just check if a thread is done? So unblocking join
Ploppz: What do you mean by unblocking join?
nonblocking*
nox: how can I produce the &'static [i32; 0] then?
use &[] directly would certainly pose a type mismatch, and transmute is not allowed for initializer of static currently
xidorn: I meant with unsafe code.
And a pointer cast.
Stop using transmute hah.
xidorn: But I brainfarted anyway, just do pub static FOO: &'static [i32; 3] = &[1, 2, 3];
That's a thin pointer, and you should be able to use it fromC++ without any issue.
nox: even if the length is unknown in the C++ side?
xidorn: Why would that matter?
I... don't know...
nox: so in this case I should use &'static [i32; 3] but not [i32; 3] directly? is there difference on abi between a reference and an array?
xidorn: Absolutely no idea, I just know that &'static [i32; 3] is ok, and the sky is too blue outside for me to wonder about the ABI differences between passing pointers and arrays to C++. :P
For those who haven't seen it yet, I published a list of Rust bloggers in the user forum, including a spreadsheet with over 300 blogs: https://users.rust-lang.org/t/fearless-rust-bloggers/16770
I'm using Rayon and I have two `Vec<Vec<f32>>` that Iwant to zip together and then iterate over in parallel. Is that possible?
Just calling `par_iter` on the zipped iterator doesn't seem to work and I see no `zip` type method  on the ParallelIterator type
to cast a lifetime to 'static, mem::transmute is the only way I suppose?
or is there something nicer
neachdainn: zip? so you want to traverse the first element of each child vector as a Vec<f32>, then the second, ...?
mitsuhiko: I'm over my head, but something to do with Box::leak?
No. I want to iterate over `(&Vec<f32>, &Vec<f32>)`
or is there something nicer
sorry. wrong key :)
j_ey: i already have it allocated so i don't want a box
ah, got it.
neachdainn: something like this https://play.rust-lang.org/?gist=e59126e5c4decc503a2b90632a45e7d7&version=stable (sorry about the sum, it was the quickest way I could consume the iterator :P)?
Ah. `par_iter` and then zip. Thanks!
you're welcome, good luck!
